body: :+1: This looks good.  I will merge it.

Looks good to me :+1:

@mfranklin let us know if this works for submitting PRs.

I love the idea of using vagrant.  

From a process perspective, we ask that you 
1) Join the dev list
2) Have most of the conversation around new approaches and ideas on the dev list
3) Create issues that you are going to submit PRs for in JIRA (https://issues.apache.org/jira)
4) Reference your JIRA issues in your PRs

I think YAML [supports line comments](http://www.yaml.org/spec/1.2/spec.html#id2780069) (but not block comments), so I guess we should go ahead and add the license message to the top of those files, too.

For the record:

This PR works just fine on Master branch, but fails on the Angular branch due to a missing dependency that is attempted to be downloaded during the `mvn install` step of the Maven role. The missing file is:

http://repository.apache.org/snapshots/org/apache/rave/rave-shindig/0.23-ANGULAR-SNAPSHOT/rave-shindig-0.23-ANGULAR-SNAPSHOT.war

Through discussion on the dev mailing list @mfranklin suggested the cause of the issue might be the fact that the Angular branch is so outdated. How right he was: the branch is currently [43 commits ahead and 62 behind Master](https://github.com/apache/rave/branches/stale). I tried my hand at rebasing, but it amounted to little more than guessing given the number of merge conflicts in a number of files I've yet to work with.

Anyway, @mfranklin mentioned he would try to update the Angular branch when he has a moment. Until that happens this PR should go unmerged.

Needs a rebase off master (the only conflict is the gitignore), additional YAML comments added, and updates to the maven role and we're good to go.

:+1:

> and we're good to go.

I spoke too soon. `cargo:run` still fails for the same reason that `mvn install` did previously: a missing file.

What file?

Yeah. We've got [a handful of rave-shindigs snapshots](http://repository.apache.org/snapshots/org/apache/rave/rave-shindig/), but no angular ones. I admit I have no idea what these snapshots are for, though. Matt Franklin, out of curiosity, do you know what these files are?

fwiw: [updated PR here](https://github.com/jmeas/rave/tree/ng-vagrant).

Still having the same issues as above. The latest news I've gathered is that it should only make a request to these external resources if they aren't built locally. This is odd as we are running mvn install locally to build the app. The fact that it's on the Vagrantbox should be of no consequence.

To shed a little light on the subject: the directory where 'mvn install' is
run from is mounted to the vagrant machine; this means that files are
written & read directly to & from the source. Thus, if we install the
dependencies on the vagrant box and then run install from the vagrant box
they will be updated on our local machine (since it's a mounted drive).
That said, these files and installs should be persistent even when 'vagrant
destroy' is run.

The problem that James and I need to resolve is the angular 0.24 git
dependency not resolving.

On Jul 7, 2014, at 1:23 PM, James Smith notifications@github.com wrote:

fwiw: updated PR here https://github.com/jmeas/rave/tree/ng-vagrant.

Still having the same issues as above. The latest news I've gathered is
that it should only make a request to these external resources if they
aren't built locally. This is odd as we are running mvn install locally to
build the app. The fact that it's on the Vagrantbox should be of no
consequence.

https://github.com/apache/rave/pull/2#issuecomment-48209091.

For a little background:  

When maven "installs" an artifact it inserts it into the local maven repository.  The default directory for which is ~/.m2/repo.  This can be changed by exporting a system environment variable of MAVEN_OPTS=-Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m -Dmaven.repo.local=/path/to/desired/repo

While the build puts artifacts in the module's target directory, those are just placeholders.  Other than having git checkout the code, there should be no git dependency.
Updated to remove the `unbuild.sh` file per @mfranklin's suggestion.
And one more update – I added instructions on how to unbuild the project.
This issue should be closed in favor of #3.
If this is no longer valid, please close
ping @carldanley
Updated @mfranklin.
Cool. #3 is in, so this can be merged whenever.

I liked the idea of having the container be independent from the maven build.  It could open the door to making the vagrant up only build a new war if it is completely rebuilt, meaning vagrant up for an existing machine just starts the version already deployed and UI developers are up and running within a min or two instead of 15.

Makes sense. If there's no way to do that with Maven being the installer of Tomcat, then that sounds like a good plan.

With that said, I'm still thinking that this PR should be merged for now. Given the current installation process, not only do you need to wait 15 minutes for Maven to install Tomcat, but then you need another 15 for Vagrant to install a second Tomcat. As long as Maven installs Tomcat, then Ansible doesn't need to.

It's a trivial task for someone to add Tomcat back into Ansible. But I'm not as familiar with Maven, so I wouldn't feel confident modifying that. I'm thinking Tomcat should be added back into Ansible at the same time that it is removed from Maven.

My suggestion would be to merge this and open a ticket on Jira suggesting that we use Ansible for Tomcat instead of Maven. You can reference this PR for folks to see how to add Ansible back in. Actually, it'd be as simple as a git revert (when the time comes):

`git revert 7ac9d69d`
fair enough :+1:

I think it is a great idea to create a new module directory specifically for the angular front-end.  I would recommend that we still keep it a (lightweight) maven artifact, so that it can be merged into the demo war and run from a single app, though that won't be how we recommend people do it in production.  If you create a ticket for this future work, we don't need to worry about it for now.  

Also, we need to determine the strategy for including the rave client code that manages the widgets, etc. IMO, we might not want to put that in this directory and just depend on it at build or runtime.  Thoughts?

Lastly, it seems that two of you are working against the same fork.  Given the fact that only one of you is submitting a patch at a time, and the amount of new code you are producing, it would be good to have the following for IP provenance:

1) Both of you should submit ICLAs to Apache. This covers your individual copyright assignment for any work you actually own.  http://www.apache.org/licenses/icla.txt.  This is your personal assignment and only covers works that you own the copyright on.  Apache requires that ICLAs be filed for individuals contributing large amounts of code

2) In any pull request that contains commits from both of you, make sure the one that is not submitting the PR notes in a comment that they also agree to the contribution

3) Try to limit the need for 2 as much as possible
This is merged, the github mirror is just not updating.  I have put a ticket in with Apache Infra https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-8110
This is merged, the github mirror is just not updating. I have put a ticket in with Apache Infra https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-8110
Thanks @mfranklin!
The mirror updated, but apparently the bot is not closing the PR.  You may need to close manually.

> If you create a ticket for this future work, we don't need to worry about it for now.

Hey Matt, I commented [over here](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/RAVE-1118) about this requirement. I think what you wrote fits in with that issue. If you'd rather it be a separate issue, just let me know and I can make a new one.

> Also, we need to determine the strategy for including the rave client code that manages the widgets, etc. IMO, we might not want to put that in this directory and just depend on it at build or runtime. Thoughts?

I imagine it will be an Angular module like any other Angular module, and I admit I don't have any strong opinions on where we put it. My initial thought was to group it as a module within the new `rave-portal-ng` directory, alongside everything else, but if you think it'd be more organized for it to be separate then that'd be fine, too. 

> Given the fact that only one of you is submitting a patch at a time, and the amount of new code you are producing, it would be good to have the following for IP provenance:

I don't have any updates to this discussion other than what's been said in the latest email thread.

Once we get this issue worked out, though, we can go ahead and merge this branch and start the new workflow we discussed in the latest call, where we open PRs directly against Rave.
This change and https://github.com/apache/rave/pull/11 touch the same file and will cause merge conflicts for one when the other merges.
:+1:  Reviewed with thumbs up on reviews.a.o
:+1:  Reviewed with thumbs up on reviews.a.o
Updated and merged with https://github.com/apache/rave/pull/10
https://github.com/apache/rave/pull/17 touches PageService as well, which might cause merge conflicts.  I'll update this PR or that one, whichever merges last.
I think the approach makes sense.  At a minimum can you create and reference the stories/sub tasks that flesh out the implementation with JPA?
Merged master and resolved conflicts.  This should be able to merge cleanly now.

I created a subtask in each of the existing stories for JPA:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/RAVE-1277
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/RAVE-1278

If they need to be broken out into their own stories, please let me know.
The ICLA has been signed, @mfranklin. Ready for merge.
@carldanley is your ICLA accepted and do you agree that the commits in this PR should be merged?
@carldanley is out this week, so he won't respond 'til Monday at the latest, and tomorrow at the earliest.
@mfranklin, accepted and agreed :)

Given the large degree of change in this PR, I recommend we take a somewhat unusual tactic for code review.  

Please propose to the list a code review time where everyone can participate via dial-in.  I will supply a number to anyone in the community that would like to participate.  

We will bring any decision points back to the list.
Sent @mfranklin.
Based on the code review that will be posted to the list, I am going to commit this to the angular branch. Further contributions will be made from the individual's fork.
:dancers:
:+1: I will merge this tomorrow if there are no objections
